articles.headline: Iran Says It Is Making Nuclear Fuel, Defying U.N.
articles.snippet: A top U.N. official was scheduled to arrive in Tehran today to make another appeal for Iran to halt its enrichment program.
articles.abstract: A top U.N. official was scheduled to arrive in Tehran today to make another appeal for Iran to halt its enrichment program.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN, April 11 — Iran announced Tuesday that its nuclear engineers had advanced to a new phase in the enrichment of uranium, and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and a series of the country's ruling clerics declared that the nation would now speed ahead, in defiance of a United Nations Security Council warning, to produce nuclear fuel on an industrial scale.
articles.byline: By NAZILA FATHI, DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

articles.headline: Berlusconi Says He Will Contest Italy Vote Tally
articles.snippet: The prime minister challenged his opponent's wisp of a victory, suggesting a recount, or a German-style grand coalition government.
articles.abstract: The prime minister challenged his opponent's wisp of a victory, suggesting a recount, or a German-style grand coalition government.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME, April 11 — Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Tuesday challenged his opponent's wisp of a victory in the divisive national elections, alternately suggesting a recount, or a German-style grand coalition government.

articles.headline: Seeking Ancestry in DNA Ties Uncovered by Tests
articles.snippet: Ethnic ancestry tests are spurring a thorough exploration of the question, What is in it for me?
articles.abstract: Ethnic ancestry tests are spurring a thorough exploration of the question, What is in it for me?
articles.lead_paragraph: Alan Moldawer's adopted twins, Matt and Andrew, had always thought of themselves as white. But when it came time for them to apply to college last year, Mr. Moldawer thought it might be worth investigating the origins of their slightly tan-tinted skin, with a new DNA kit that he had heard could determine an individual's genetic ancestry.

articles.headline: A Health Fix That Is Not Fantasy
articles.snippet: TO a lot of thoughtful people, the only way to fix the health insurance crisis is to get the federal government to cover everyone. Britain, Canada, Japan and a number of other rich countries do so, and they each spend less money on health care tha...
articles.abstract: TO a lot of thoughtful people, the only way to fix the health insurance crisis is to get the federal government to cover everyone. Britain, Canada, Japan and a number of other rich countries do so, and they each spend less money on health care than this country does. They also don't have major companies, like General Motors, flirting with bankruptcy in large part because of the cost of health benefits.     It is a pretty good argument, but it has an undeniable flaw. There is almost no chance of universal coverage happening anytime in the foreseeable future.
articles.lead_paragraph: TO a lot of thoughtful people, the only way to fix the health insurance crisis is to get the federal government to cover everyone. Britain, Canada, Japan and a number of other rich countries do so, and they each spend less money on health care than this country does. They also don't have major companies, like General Motors, flirting with bankruptcy in large part because of the cost of health benefits.

articles.headline: Merck Jury Adds $9 Million in Damages
articles.snippet: Merck's legal morass just got a whole lot stickier. A jury in Atlantic City yesterday found that Merck had misled the Food and Drug Administration about the dangers of its painkiller Vioxx and acted with wanton disregard for patients taking the dr...
articles.abstract: Merck's legal morass just got a whole lot stickier. A jury in Atlantic City yesterday found that Merck had misled the Food and Drug Administration about the dangers of its painkiller Vioxx and acted with wanton disregard for patients taking the drug.     By a vote of 7 to 1, the juroy awarded $9 million in punitive damages to John McDarby, 77, who had a heart attack in 2004 after taking Vioxx for four years, and his wife, Irma. Last week, it gave the McDarbys $4.5 million in compensatory damages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merck's legal morass just got a whole lot stickier. A jury in Atlantic City yesterday found that Merck had misled the Food and Drug Administration about the dangers of its painkiller Vioxx and acted with wanton disregard for patients taking the drug.

articles.headline: $50 Million Puts Ali in Ring With Elvis and 'American Idol'
articles.snippet: The media entrepreneur who controls the rights to Elvis Presley, ''American Idol'' and the soccer star David Beckham has added another star to his roster: Muhammad Ali.     Robert F. X. Sillerman, the chief executive of the entertainment company C...
articles.abstract: The media entrepreneur who controls the rights to Elvis Presley, ''American Idol'' and the soccer star David Beckham has added another star to his roster: Muhammad Ali.     Robert F. X. Sillerman, the chief executive of the entertainment company CKX, announced yesterday that his company had paid $50 million for an 80 percent stake in Mr. Ali's name, image and likeness. The other 20 percent will be retained by Mr. Ali and his company, GOAT (short for the ''greatest of all time'').

articles.headline: Nasdaq Buys Stake in London Exchange
articles.snippet: Nasdaq said yesterday that it had bought a 15 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange, Europe's largest stock market, in a move to expand its international profile.      The purchase makes Nasdaq the largest shareholder in the exchange and come...
articles.abstract: Nasdaq said yesterday that it had bought a 15 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange, Europe's largest stock market, in a move to expand its international profile.      The purchase makes Nasdaq the largest shareholder in the exchange and comes one month after Nasdaq's $4.1 billion bid for the exchange was rebuffed as inadequate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nasdaq said yesterday that it had bought a 15 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange, Europe's largest stock market, in a move to expand its international profile.

articles.headline: Seeking Ancestry in DNA Ties Uncovered by Tests
articles.snippet: Alan Moldawer's adopted twins, Matt and Andrew, had always thought of themselves as white. But when it came time for them to apply to college last year, Mr. Moldawer thought it might be worth investigating the origins of their slightly tan-tinted ...
articles.abstract: Alan Moldawer's adopted twins, Matt and Andrew, had always thought of themselves as white. But when it came time for them to apply to college last year, Mr. Moldawer thought it might be worth investigating the origins of their slightly tan-tinted skin, with a new DNA kit that he had heard could determine an individual's genetic ancestry.     The results, designating the boys 9 percent Native American and 11 percent northern African, arrived too late for the admissions process. But Mr. Moldawer, a business executive in Silver Spring, Md., says they could be useful in obtaining financial aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alan Moldawer's adopted twins, Matt and Andrew, had always thought of themselves as white. But when it came time for them to apply to college last year, Mr. Moldawer thought it might be worth investigating the origins of their slightly tan-tinted skin, with a new DNA kit that he had heard could determine an individual's genetic ancestry.

articles.headline: 2 Wall Street Employees Charged With Insider Trading
articles.snippet: Ever since Michael Douglas declared that ''greed is good'' in the 1987 movie ''Wall Street,'' the character he played, Gordon Gekko, has been the face of insider trading on Wall Street.      But it was $2 million in profits made by a 63-year-old r...
articles.abstract: Ever since Michael Douglas declared that ''greed is good'' in the 1987 movie ''Wall Street,'' the character he played, Gordon Gekko, has been the face of insider trading on Wall Street.      But it was $2 million in profits made by a 63-year-old retired seamstress in Croatia that tipped off the Securities and Exchange Commission about an ambitious and unusually creative insider trading ring, investigators say. That lead culminated in the arrests yesterday of two junior-level employees at Goldman Sachs and Merrill Lynch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since Michael Douglas declared that "greed is good" in the 1987 movie "Wall Street," the character he played, Gordon Gekko, has been the face of insider trading on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Iran Says It Is Making Nuclear Fuel, Defying U.N.
articles.snippet: Iran announced Tuesday that its nuclear engineers had advanced to a new phase in the enrichment of uranium, and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and a series of the country's ruling clerics declared that the nation would now speed ahead, in defiance ...
articles.abstract: Iran announced Tuesday that its nuclear engineers had advanced to a new phase in the enrichment of uranium, and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and a series of the country's ruling clerics declared that the nation would now speed ahead, in defiance of a United Nations Security Council warning, to produce nuclear fuel on an industrial scale.      ''Iran has joined the nuclear countries of the world,'' Mr. Ahmadinejad said during a large, carefully staged and nationally televised celebration in Mashhad, which included video presentations of each step of the nuclear process that he declared Iran had mastered. ''The nuclear fuel cycle at the laboratory level has been completed, and uranium with the desired enrichment for nuclear power plants was achieved.''
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN, April 11 - Iran announced Tuesday that its nuclear engineers had advanced to a new phase in the enrichment of uranium, and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and a series of the country's ruling clerics declared that the nation would now speed ahead, in defiance of a United Nations Security Council warning, to produce nuclear fuel on an industrial scale.
articles.byline: This article is by Nazila Fathi, David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Berlusconi Says He Will Contest Italy Vote Tally
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Tuesday challenged his opponent's wisp of a victory in the divisive national elections, alternately suggesting a recount, or a German-style grand coalition government.      Although final results announced Tuesd...
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Tuesday challenged his opponent's wisp of a victory in the divisive national elections, alternately suggesting a recount, or a German-style grand coalition government.      Although final results announced Tuesday showed his center-left opponent, Romano Prodi, with a thin lead in both houses of Parliament, Mr. Berlusconi contended that the vote was so close that there was ample room for error.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME, April 11 - Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Tuesday challenged his opponent's wisp of a victory in the divisive national elections, alternately suggesting a recount, or a German-style grand coalition government.

articles.headline: From the Back Office, a Casino Can Change the Slot Machine in Seconds
articles.snippet: From his small back office in the Treasure Island casino, Justin Beltram may soon be able to change the wheels of fortune instantly.     Mr. Beltram, a casino executive, is the point man in a high-technology experiment that could alter the face of...
articles.abstract: From his small back office in the Treasure Island casino, Justin Beltram may soon be able to change the wheels of fortune instantly.     Mr. Beltram, a casino executive, is the point man in a high-technology experiment that could alter the face of slot machines, and their insides, too.

articles.headline: Judges Set Hurdles for Lethal Injection
articles.snippet: Judges in several states have started to put up potentially insurmountable roadblocks to the use of lethal injections to execute condemned inmates.      Their decisions are based on new evidence suggesting that prisoners have endured agonizing exe...
articles.abstract: Judges in several states have started to put up potentially insurmountable roadblocks to the use of lethal injections to execute condemned inmates.      Their decisions are based on new evidence suggesting that prisoners have endured agonizing executions. In response, judges are insisting that doctors take an active role in supervising executions, even though the American Medical Association's code of ethics prohibits that.
articles.lead_paragraph: Judges in several states have started to put up potentially insurmountable roadblocks to the use of lethal injections to execute condemned inmates.

articles.headline: White House Engages Iran With Words
articles.snippet: One of President Bush's most senior foreign policy advisers spoke with unusual candor last week about the quandary the White House faces as it tries to confront Iran.     ''The problem is that our policy has been all carrots and no sticks,'' the a...
articles.abstract: One of President Bush's most senior foreign policy advisers spoke with unusual candor last week about the quandary the White House faces as it tries to confront Iran.     ''The problem is that our policy has been all carrots and no sticks,'' the adviser told a gathering of academics and outside strategists. ''And the Iranians know it.''
articles.lead_paragraph: One of President Bush's most senior foreign policy advisers spoke with unusual candor last week about the quandary the White House faces as it tries to confront Iran.
